trans-unit.source: Create an ASP.NET API app in Azure App Service using Visual Studio 2015
trans-unit.target: Create an ASP.NET API app in Azure App Service using Visual Studio 2015

trans-unit.source: Learn how to to create an ASP.NET API app in Azure App Service, using Visual Studio 2015
trans-unit.target: Learn how to to create an ASP.NET API app in Azure App Service, using Visual Studio 2015

trans-unit.source: In this tutorial you create an ASP.NET Web API 2 project using <linkText>Visual Studio 2015 RC</linkText><title></title>, and configure it for deployment to the cloud as an <linkText>API app</linkText><title></title> in <linkText>Azure App Service</linkText><title></title>.
trans-unit.target: In this tutorial you create an ASP.NET Web API 2 project using <linkText>Visual Studio 2015 RC</linkText><title></title>, and configure it for deployment to the cloud as an <linkText>API app</linkText><title></title> in <linkText>Azure App Service</linkText><title></title>.

trans-unit.source: You also deploy the project to Azure.
trans-unit.target: You also deploy the project to Azure.

trans-unit.source: At the end of the tutorial you'll have an API app running in the Azure cloud.
trans-unit.target: At the end of the tutorial you'll have an API app running in the Azure cloud.

trans-unit.source: The tutorial assumes you know how to work with files and folders in Visual Studio Solution Explorer.
trans-unit.target: The tutorial assumes you know how to work with files and folders in Visual Studio Solution Explorer.

trans-unit.source: The tutorial works with the currently released version of ASP.NET Web API.
trans-unit.target: The tutorial works with the currently released version of ASP.NET Web API.

trans-unit.source: For information about how to create an ASP.NET MVC 6 API app, see this blog post: <linkText>https://alexanderzeitler.com/articles/Deploying-a-ASP-NET-MVC-6-API-as-Azure-API-App-in-Azure-App-Services/</linkText><title>Deploying a ASP.NET MVC 6 API as Azure API App in Azure App Services</title>.
trans-unit.target: For information about how to create an ASP.NET MVC 6 API app, see this blog post: <linkText>https://alexanderzeitler.com/articles/Deploying-a-ASP-NET-MVC-6-API-as-Azure-API-App-in-Azure-App-Services/</linkText><title>Deploying a ASP.NET MVC 6 API as Azure API App in Azure App Services</title>.

trans-unit.source: This tutorial requires version 2.6 or later of the Azure SDK for .NET.
trans-unit.target: This tutorial requires version 2.6 or later of the Azure SDK for .NET.

trans-unit.source: Visual Studio 2015 RC does not yet have an API app project template, so to create an API app project you start with the Web API project template.
trans-unit.target: Visual Studio 2015 RC does not yet have an API app project template, so to create an API app project you start with the Web API project template.

trans-unit.source: Open Visual Studio 2015 RC.
trans-unit.target: Open Visual Studio 2015 RC.

trans-unit.source: Click File > New Project.
trans-unit.target: Click File > New Project.

trans-unit.source: Under Templates, click Web, and then click the ASP.NET Web Application template.
trans-unit.target: Under Templates, click Web, and then click the ASP.NET Web Application template.

trans-unit.source: Name the project ContactsList
trans-unit.target: Name the project ContactsList

trans-unit.source: Make sure that the Add Application Insights to Project check box is cleared.
trans-unit.target: Make sure that the Add Application Insights to Project check box is cleared.

trans-unit.source: Click OK.
trans-unit.target: Click OK.

trans-unit.source: In the New ASP.NET Project dialog under ASP.NET 4.6 Templates, select the Empty project template.
trans-unit.target: In the New ASP.NET Project dialog under ASP.NET 4.6 Templates, select the Empty project template.

trans-unit.source: Select the Web API check box.
trans-unit.target: Select the Web API check box.

trans-unit.source: Clear the Host in the cloud check box.
trans-unit.target: Clear the Host in the cloud check box.

trans-unit.source: Click OK.
trans-unit.target: Click OK.

trans-unit.source: The App Service runtime for API apps is provided by the <linkText>Microsoft.Azure.AppService.ApiApps.Service</linkText><title></title> NuGet package, and dynamic <linkText>Swagger</linkText><title>Official Swagger information</title> API metadata generation is provided by the <linkText>Swashbuckle</linkText><title></title> NuGet package.
trans-unit.target: The App Service runtime for API apps is provided by the <linkText>Microsoft.Azure.AppService.ApiApps.Service</linkText><title></title> NuGet package, and dynamic <linkText>Swagger</linkText><title>Official Swagger information</title> API metadata generation is provided by the <linkText>Swashbuckle</linkText><title></title> NuGet package.

trans-unit.source: Note: When you install the Swashbuckle package, an API test page is enabled by default.
trans-unit.target: Note: When you install the Swashbuckle package, an API test page is enabled by default.

trans-unit.source: If you publish the API app and set its access level to Public (anonymous), anyone who finds the test page URL can use it to call your API.
trans-unit.target: If you publish the API app and set its access level to Public (anonymous), anyone who finds the test page URL can use it to call your API.

trans-unit.source: You'll use the test page later in this tutorial.
trans-unit.target: You'll use the test page later in this tutorial.

trans-unit.source: Click Tools > NuGet Package Manager > Package Manager Console.
trans-unit.target: Click Tools > NuGet Package Manager > Package Manager Console.

trans-unit.source: In the Package Manager Console (PMC), enter the following commands.
trans-unit.target: In the Package Manager Console (PMC), enter the following commands.

trans-unit.source: You might have to wait several minutes after the PMC displays the message indicating that it is checking dependencies.
trans-unit.target: You might have to wait several minutes after the PMC displays the message indicating that it is checking dependencies.

trans-unit.source: The metadata that enables a Web API project to be deployed as an API app is contained in an apiapp.json file and a Metadata folder with its subfolders and files.
trans-unit.target: The metadata that enables a Web API project to be deployed as an API app is contained in an apiapp.json file and a Metadata folder with its subfolders and files.

trans-unit.source: In the following steps you add these files with default values.
trans-unit.target: In the following steps you add these files with default values.

trans-unit.source: The <linkText>API app metadata</linkText><title></title> section later in the tutorial explains how to customize this metadata.
trans-unit.target: The <linkText>API app metadata</linkText><title></title> section later in the tutorial explains how to customize this metadata.

trans-unit.source: In the project folder, create a .json file named apiapp.json, and replace the contents of the new file with the following JSON text.
trans-unit.target: In the project folder, create a .json file named apiapp.json, and replace the contents of the new file with the following JSON text.

trans-unit.source: In the project folder, create a folder named Metadata, and in the Metadata folder, create a folder named deploymentTemplates.
trans-unit.target: In the project folder, create a folder named Metadata, and in the Metadata folder, create a folder named deploymentTemplates.

trans-unit.source: In the deploymentTemplates folder, create a .json file named apiappconfig.azureresource.json, and replace the contents of the new file with the following JSON text.
trans-unit.target: In the deploymentTemplates folder, create a .json file named apiappconfig.azureresource.json, and replace the contents of the new file with the following JSON text.

trans-unit.source: In the following steps you add code for a simple HTTP Get method that returns a hard-coded list of contacts.
trans-unit.target: In the following steps you add code for a simple HTTP Get method that returns a hard-coded list of contacts.

trans-unit.source: Create a Models folder in the project folder if it doesn't already exist.
trans-unit.target: Create a Models folder in the project folder if it doesn't already exist.

trans-unit.source: In the Models folder, add a class file named Contact.cs, and replace the contents of the file with the following code.
trans-unit.target: In the Models folder, add a class file named Contact.cs, and replace the contents of the file with the following code.

trans-unit.source: Right-click the Controllers folder, and select Add > Controller.
trans-unit.target: Right-click the Controllers folder, and select Add > Controller.

trans-unit.source: In the Add Scaffold dialog, select the Web API 2 Controller - Empty option, and click Add.
trans-unit.target: In the Add Scaffold dialog, select the Web API 2 Controller - Empty option, and click Add.

trans-unit.source: Name the controller ContactsController, and click Add.
trans-unit.target: Name the controller ContactsController, and click Add.

trans-unit.source: Once the ContactsController.cs file has been created, replace the contents of the file with the following code.
trans-unit.target: Once the ContactsController.cs file has been created, replace the contents of the file with the following code.

trans-unit.source: To view the API test page, perform the following steps.
trans-unit.target: To view the API test page, perform the following steps.

trans-unit.source: Run the app locally (CTRL-F5), and add /swagger to the end of the URL in the browser's address bar.
trans-unit.target: Run the app locally (CTRL-F5), and add /swagger to the end of the URL in the browser's address bar.

trans-unit.source: Click Contacts > Get > Try it out, and you see that the API is functioning and returns the expected result.
trans-unit.target: Click Contacts > Get > Try it out, and you see that the API is functioning and returns the expected result.

trans-unit.source: Create an API app in the <linkText>Azure preview portal</linkText><title></title>.
trans-unit.target: Create an API app in the <linkText>Azure preview portal</linkText><title></title>.

trans-unit.source: Click New > Web + Mobile > API App.
trans-unit.target: Click New > Web + Mobile > API App.

trans-unit.source: In Name enter ContactsList.
trans-unit.target: In Name enter ContactsList.

trans-unit.source: In App Service Plan click Create New and enter a name, for example: ContactsList.
trans-unit.target: In App Service Plan click Create New and enter a name, for example: ContactsList.

trans-unit.source: For more information about App Service plans, see <linkText>Azure App Service plans in-depth overview</linkText><title></title>.
trans-unit.target: For more information about App Service plans, see <linkText>Azure App Service plans in-depth overview</linkText><title></title>.

trans-unit.source: Click Pricing Tier > View all > Free > Select to select the free pricing tier.
trans-unit.target: Click Pricing Tier > View all > Free > Select to select the free pricing tier.

trans-unit.source: You can use a paid pricing tier, but it isn't required for this tutorial.
trans-unit.target: You can use a paid pricing tier, but it isn't required for this tutorial.

trans-unit.source: In Resource Group, click Create New and then enter a name, for example: ContactsList.
trans-unit.target: In Resource Group, click Create New and then enter a name, for example: ContactsList.

trans-unit.source: For more information about resource groups, see <linkText>Using resource groups to manage your Azure resources</linkText><title></title>.
trans-unit.target: For more information about resource groups, see <linkText>Using resource groups to manage your Azure resources</linkText><title></title>.

trans-unit.source: If you have more than one subscription, select the subscription you want to use.
trans-unit.target: If you have more than one subscription, select the subscription you want to use.

trans-unit.source: Choose a location close to you.
trans-unit.target: Choose a location close to you.

trans-unit.source: Click Create.
trans-unit.target: Click Create.

trans-unit.source: When Azure finishes creating the API app, set the API app's access level to Public (anonymous).
trans-unit.target: When Azure finishes creating the API app, set the API app's access level to Public (anonymous).

trans-unit.source: Click Browse > Resource Groups > [the resource group you created] > [the API app you created].
trans-unit.target: Click Browse > Resource Groups > [the resource group you created] > [the API app you created].

trans-unit.source: Click Settings > Application settings.
trans-unit.target: Click Settings > Application settings.

trans-unit.source: Change Access Level to Public (anonymous).
trans-unit.target: Change Access Level to Public (anonymous).

trans-unit.source: Click Save.
trans-unit.target: Click Save.

trans-unit.source: Make a note of the name of the underlying web app that hosts the API app.
trans-unit.target: Make a note of the name of the underlying web app that hosts the API app.

trans-unit.source: You'll use this when you deploy the Visual Studio project.
trans-unit.target: You'll use this when you deploy the Visual Studio project.

trans-unit.source: Under API app host, click ContactsList.
trans-unit.target: Under API app host, click ContactsList.

trans-unit.source: The name is in the title of the API app host blade.
trans-unit.target: The name is in the title of the API app host blade.

trans-unit.source: API apps are essentially web apps for which Azure provides additional features for web service functionality.
trans-unit.target: API apps are essentially web apps for which Azure provides additional features for web service functionality.

trans-unit.source: In Visual Studio 2015 RC, you publish to the API app's underlying web app because the Publish Web wizard does not have a selection specifically for API apps.
trans-unit.target: In Visual Studio 2015 RC, you publish to the API app's underlying web app because the Publish Web wizard does not have a selection specifically for API apps.

trans-unit.source: In Visual Studio Solution Explorer, right-click the project and then in the context menu click Publish.
trans-unit.target: In Visual Studio Solution Explorer, right-click the project and then in the context menu click Publish.

trans-unit.source: In the Profile step of the Publish Web wizard, click Microsoft Azure Web Apps.
trans-unit.target: In the Profile step of the Publish Web wizard, click Microsoft Azure Web Apps.

trans-unit.source: In the Existing Web Apps drop-down list, select the entry with the API app name that you noted earlier.
trans-unit.target: In the Existing Web Apps drop-down list, select the entry with the API app name that you noted earlier.

trans-unit.source: Click Publish.
trans-unit.target: Click Publish.

trans-unit.source: Your browser opens to the web app URL and shows an "API app has been created" page.
trans-unit.target: Your browser opens to the web app URL and shows an "API app has been created" page.

trans-unit.source: In the browser address bar, add "swagger/" to the end of the URL, for example:
trans-unit.target: In the browser address bar, add "swagger/" to the end of the URL, for example:

trans-unit.source: You see the same Swagger UI that you saw earlier running locally, but now it is running in the cloud.
trans-unit.target: You see the same Swagger UI that you saw earlier running locally, but now it is running in the cloud.

trans-unit.source: Click Contacts > Get > Try it out, and you see that the API is functioning and returns the expected result.
trans-unit.target: Click Contacts > Get > Try it out, and you see that the API is functioning and returns the expected result.

trans-unit.source: In this section, you navigate to the portal to view the API definition for the API app that you just created.
trans-unit.target: In this section, you navigate to the portal to view the API definition for the API app that you just created.

trans-unit.source: In the Azure preview portal, navigate to the API app blade for your API app: click Browse > Resource Groups > [the resource group you created] > [the API app you created].
trans-unit.target: In the Azure preview portal, navigate to the API app blade for your API app: click Browse > Resource Groups > [the resource group you created] > [the API app you created].

trans-unit.source: Click API Definition.
trans-unit.target: Click API Definition.

trans-unit.source: The app's API Definition blade shows the list of API operations that you defined when you created the app.
trans-unit.target: The app's API Definition blade shows the list of API operations that you defined when you created the app.

trans-unit.source: (If you followed this tutorial you'll only see a Get operation.)
trans-unit.target: (If you followed this tutorial you'll only see a Get operation.)

trans-unit.source: <linkText>API Definition</linkText>
trans-unit.target: <linkText>API Definition</linkText>

trans-unit.source: Go back to the project in Visual Studio and add the following code to the ContactsController.cs file.
trans-unit.target: Go back to the project in Visual Studio and add the following code to the ContactsController.cs file.

trans-unit.source: This code adds a Post method that can be used to post new Contact instances to the API.
trans-unit.target: This code adds a Post method that can be used to post new Contact instances to the API.

trans-unit.source: <linkText>Adding the Post method to the controller</linkText>
trans-unit.target: <linkText>Adding the Post method to the controller</linkText>

trans-unit.source: Publish the project as you did earlier.
trans-unit.target: Publish the project as you did earlier.

trans-unit.source: (In Solution Explorer, right-click the project and click Publish, and then click Publish in the Publish Web wizard.)
trans-unit.target: (In Solution Explorer, right-click the project and click Publish, and then click Publish in the Publish Web wizard.)

trans-unit.source: Once the publish process has completed, go back to the portal, and restart the gateway as you did earlier.
trans-unit.target: Once the publish process has completed, go back to the portal, and restart the gateway as you did earlier.

trans-unit.source: In the portal, go back to the API Definition blade.
trans-unit.target: In the portal, go back to the API Definition blade.

trans-unit.source: You see the new API endpoint that you just created and deployed to your Azure subscription.
trans-unit.target: You see the new API endpoint that you just created and deployed to your Azure subscription.

trans-unit.source: <linkText>API Definition</linkText>
trans-unit.target: <linkText>API Definition</linkText>

trans-unit.source: You have now created and deployed an API app using Visual Studio 2015 RC.
trans-unit.target: You have now created and deployed an API app using Visual Studio 2015 RC.

trans-unit.source: For more documentation about API apps, see the entries in the navigation pane that shows on the left side of the page (for wide browser windows) or at the top of the page (for narrow browser windows).
trans-unit.target: For more documentation about API apps, see the entries in the navigation pane that shows on the left side of the page (for wide browser windows) or at the top of the page (for narrow browser windows).

trans-unit.source: Most of the API app documentation currently shows Visual Studio 2013, but much of it can be used with VS 2015 because the UI is similar, the code you write is the same, and the portal UI is the same.
trans-unit.target: Most of the API app documentation currently shows Visual Studio 2013, but much of it can be used with VS 2015 because the UI is similar, the code you write is the same, and the portal UI is the same.
